links.title: Federal Reserve A Bigger Headwind To Trump's Economy Than China
links.description: Blame Jerome Powell for this week's roller coaster ride on the Dow. Every single time the Fed chairman speaks about interest rates, he has investors from sea to shining sea hitting the sell button. Powell is a bigger headwind to Trump's economy than China.

links.title: Alphabet: Playing A Dangerous Game
links.description: At this point, Alphabet ( GOOG) ( GOOGL) hasn't seen any impact to long-term financial targets due to tangles with regulators. Though, the company is playing a dangerous game with regulators. The $175 dip in the stock to a recent low below $1,115 is an opportunity unless the search giant continues to antagonize regulators.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomangell/2018/10/10/trump-administration-seeks-public-comments-on-marijuana-reclassification/#3ca30e62749a

links.title: Trump Administration Seeks Public Comments On Marijuana Reclassification
links.description: The federal government wants your input on whether marijuana should be reclassified under global drug treaties to which the U.S. is a party. Specifically, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is asking for public comments about the "abuse potential, actual abuse, medical usefulness, trafficking, and impact of scheduling changes on availability for medical use" of cannabis and several other substances now under international review.

links.title: Above The 40 - Confidence And A Conditional Reprieve Amid Oversold Lows
links.description: AT40 (T2108), the percentage of stocks trading above their respective 40-day moving averages (DMAs), fell as low as 9.4% on Friday. AT40 dropped as low as 8.6% intraday during the February swoon.

 https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.cnbc.com/amp/2018/10/14/saudi-stocks-plunge-on-khashoggi-fallout-biggest-drop--since-2014.html

links.title: Saudi stocks plunge 7% on Khashoggi fallout; biggest drop since 2014
links.description: YASIN AKGUL | AFP | Getty Images Saudi Arabia's stock market plunged on Sunday as investors worried about deteriorating relations with the international community after the disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi. After nearly two hours of trade the index was down 7.0 percent, its biggest drop since December 2014, when oil prices were crashing.
